document: Lecture 1 – Introduction to Algorithms: An overview covering the definition and properties of algorithms, proof techniques (induction), asymptotic analysis, computational models, and examples of algorithmic complexity.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes an algorithm?
options: A finite sequence of instructions that always terminates for all inputs
An infinite loop that may or may not terminate
Any random set of operations on data
Only a proof technique used in mathematics
questions.answer: A finite sequence of instructions that always terminates for all inputs

questions.question: Which property is NOT part of the formal definition of an algorithm?
What type of induction is used in the proof that 1+2+…+n = n(n+1)/2?
Which of the following is an example of a logarithmic time algorithm?
What does Big‑O notation describe?
options: The exact running time of an algorithm for all inputs
An upper bound on the growth rate of a function
A lower bound on memory usage
questions.answer: An upper bound on the growth rate of a function

questions.question: In which computational model are all memory cells assumed to have equal access cost?
Which of the following is NOT a valid classification by design paradigm?
What best‑case complexity of finding the smallest element in an unsorted array of size n?
Which statement about worst‑case complexity is true?
options: It gives a lower bound on running time
It always equals the average case
It provides an upper bound on running time for all inputs
It is irrelevant for algorithm design
questions.answer: It provides an upper bound on running time for all inputs

questions.question: What does the term 'effectiveness' refer to in algorithm definitions?
options: The number of steps taken by an algorithm
Whether the output is correct given a valid input
How fast the algorithm runs on average
questions.answer: Whether the output is correct given a valid input

questions.question: Which of these functions has growth rate Θ(n log n)?
Which of the following algorithms is known as the fastest possible comparison‑based sort?
In a RAM model, function calls take how many time units?
Which of the following best describes 'asymptotic performance' in a course?
options: It refers to the precise runtime for small inputs
It studies how algorithms behave as input size grows large
It only looks at memory usage
It is about hardware power consumption
questions.answer: It studies how algorithms behave as input size grows large

questions.question: Which of the following is a valid example of a non‑deterministic algorithm?
Which of the following is a correct statement about inductive proofs?
options: They prove statements for all n≥0 by base case only
They can be applied to sequences with infinite length
Proofs require a base case and an inductive step
Induction never works for algorithmic complexity
questions.answer: Proofs require a base case and an inductive step

questions.question: Which of the following best describes 'lower bound' in algorithm analysis?
options: It is a lower limit on maximum memory usage
An upper bound on running time
A guarantee that every algorithm must exceed
The minimum expected running time for any algorithm solving the same problem
questions.answer: The minimum expected running time for any algorithm solving the same problem

questions.question: Which of these is an example of a constant‑time operation?
options: Sorting a list of size n
Printing an array of length n
Multiplying two matrices of size n×n

questions.question: Which algorithmic paradigm is best for problems that require searching through all possible solutions?
Which of the following best captures the meaning of 'complexity' in algorithmic analysis?
options: How many steps a test case runs
The rate at which data is processed
A function that describes how often an algorithm’s runtime changes with input size
The number of hardware instructions executed
questions.answer: A function that describes how often an algorithm’s runtime changes with input size

questions.question: Which of the following statements about average‑case complexity is correct?
options: Average case always equals the worst case
It provides an expected running time over random inputs
Worst case is better than average
